paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.title: The Effect of the SLED Installation on Extracted and Lost Beam at the Australian Synchrotron Linac.
paper.abstract: A recent upgrade to the high power RF network of the linac at the Australian Synchrotron included a SLED Type 1 Pulse Compressor allowing for the operation of its 100 MeV linac using a single klystron. We explore the effects of the SLED installation on the properties of the beam extracted from the linac with a particular focus on the energy spread and bunch train profile. Additionally, the optical fibre beam loss monitor (oBLM), also recently commissioned, was employed to provide shot-by-shot feedback on loss location and intensity to investigate the change in beam losses.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Design Status of an Electron Source Test Lab at the Canadian Light Source
paper.abstract: An electron source test laboratory is being designed and implemented at the Canadian Light Source. Scientists at the CLS will investigate both the properties of different gun designs and the production of femtosecond pulsed, bright, low emittance beams. This lab is a means to determining the proper gun design required as a backup in the current synchrotron, and the future facility electron source. The labs location, next to the 250MeV electron linac, requires sufficient radiation shielding and integration into the existing access control and interlock system, as well as sufficient power and cooling supplies for the lab equipment. Currently, a budget is being developed for the lab by considering the requirements of various electron guns and their diagnostics.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Application of a Phase Space Beam Position and Size Monitor for Synchrotron Radiation
paper.abstract: We will report on a system (ps-BPM) that can measure the electron source vertical position and angular motion along with the vertical source size and angular size at a single location in a synchrotron bend magnet beamline*. This system uses a combination of a monochromator and a filter with a K-edge to which the monochromator was tuned in energy. The vertical distribution of the beam with and without the filter was simultaneously visualized with an imaging detector. The small range of angles from the source onto the monochromator crystals creates an energy range that allows part of the beam to be below the K-edge and the other part above. Measurement of the beam vertical location without the absorber and edge vertical location with the absorber allowes measurement of the source position and angle. The beam width and edge width give information about the vertical electron source size and angular distribution. The ps-BPM measurements have been made where the electron beam size and angular distribution was adjusted using skew quads. The ps-BPM measurements correlate well with modeling of the ps-BPM system as well as conventional beam size measurements using a pinhole.
paper.footnote: * A phase-space beam position monitor for synchrotron radiation. J Synchrotron Radiat, 2015. 22(4): p. 946-55.

paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.sub_class: T31 Subsystems, Technology and Components, Other
paper.title: Beam Instability Induced by RF System of an FEL-THZ Source
paper.abstract: An SLAC-like Compact Linac installed on the HUST FEL-THz has been used as an injector to produce high power THz radiation. To meet the requirements of monochromaticity and repeatability for FEL, performance of electron beam and stability of RF system are notable. According to the existing facility, based on measurement results of RF jitter, instability of beam has been calculated, and it has been verified in relevant experiments. Furthermore, stability targets in RF system has been pro-posed in this paper.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Norm-optimal Iterative Learning Control to Cancel Beam Loading Effect on the Accelerating Field
paper.abstract: Iterative learning control (ILC) is an open loop control strategy that improves the performance of a repetitive system through learning from previous iterations. ILC can be used to compensate for a repetitive disturbance like the beam loading effect in resonators. In this work, we aim to use norm-optimal ILC to cancel beam loading effect. Norm-optimal ILC updates the control signal with the goal of minimizing a performance index, which results in monotonic convergence. Simulation results show that this controller improves beam loading compensation compared to a PI controller.

paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.title: Dynamic Pressure in the LHC - Influence of Ions Induced by Ionization of Residual Gas by Both the Proton Beam and the Electron Cloud
paper.abstract: Ultra-High Vacuum is an essential requirement to reach design performances in high-energy particle colliders. For the future HL-LHC or FCC study, the understanding of the beam interactions with the vacuum chamber is fundamental to provide solutions to mitigate the pressure rises induced by electronic, photonic and ionic molecular desorption. Studies were performed on the ions, produced by molecular ionization generated by the proton beam and the electron cloud, and stimulating molecular desorption by the surface bombardment. In-situ measurements were carried out, on the LHC Vacuum Pilot Sector (VPS)*, to monitor the dynamic pressure, and to collect the electrical signals due to the electron cloud and to the ions interacting with the vacuum chamber walls. Experimental measurements of electrical signals recorded by copper electrodes were compared to calculations taking into account both the Secondary Electron Yield of copper and electron energy distribution. Finally, it seems that copper electrodes were not fully conditioned and an ion current could be estimated.
paper.agency: work supported by FCC project (CERN & LAL-CNRS-IN2P3)
paper.footnote: * THE LHC VACUUM PILOT-SECTOR PROJECT B. Henrist, V. Baglin, G. Bregliozzi, and P. Chiggiato, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland Proceedings of IPAC2014, Dresden, Germany.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Wire Scanner for High Intensity Ion Beam*
paper.abstract: The goal of the project is to develop a Wire-Scanner compatible with low energy - high intensity ion beams and adaptable to various beam chamber diameters. The purpose is to obtain the 2D beam profile by passing measurement wires through the beam. Thanks to a high speed passage of measurement wires, it allows to avoid "disrupting" the beam passage, and can be considered as a non-destructive diagnosis. Wires heating and measuring issues have been solved by using tungsten wires kept in tension by a mechanical system. All driving and signal measurements are performed by a PXI based system. The synchronization of the measurements is guaranteed by an analog input board recovering the wires current and the translator position, the latter being carried out by a laser sensor. Besides this technological aspect, an optimization algorithm for beam profile reconstruction from measured data under Gaussian hypothesis has been developed. The standalone system and first experimental results are presented.
paper.agency: Part of this work supported by the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) H2020 Program under grant agreement n°662186 (MYRTE project).

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Beam Dynamics and Diagnostics for the High Energy Beam Transport Line of MINERVA Project at SCK-CEN
paper.abstract: MYRRHA will be a research infrastructure highlighted by the first prototype of a sub-critical nuclear reactor driven by a 600 MeV particle accelerator (ADS). This project aims at exploring the transmutation of long-lived nuclear wastes. A first phase is planned to validate the reliability of a 100 MeV/4 mA Protons LINAC carrying the beam toward an ISOL facility, prefiguring the real MYRRHA demonstrator at 600 MeV. This project is called MINERVA. This paper presents the status of the beam dynamic studies for the high energy beam transport lines at 100 MeV. In agreement with the project require-ments, we describe the specificities of these beam lines for which it is needed to implement a fast kicker-septum. This system will separate the beam between two main lines: toward the beam dump or the ISOL facility. We also describe the studies on the Beam Position Monitor (BPM) selected for MYRRHA. Part of this work was sup-port by the MYRTE project of the European Union.
paper.agency: French research agency and technologies (ANRT), through the program CIFRE (2018/0080 ) supported by THALES AVS FRANCE SAS.

abstract_log.comments:
This paper presents clearly the challenges and issues of the beam dynamics of the HEBT of the MINERVA project as well as the study of the BPM which will equipped this beam line. The methods used for this work precisely explained and the simulation results are well presented and discussed.
In order to improve the readability of the paper, I may propose a few corrections (mainly typos):
In INTRODUCTION, line 20 : In the sentence "Beyond the beam position, devices allow us..." The pronoun "these" can be added : "Beyond the beam position, these devices allow us..."
In section "HEBT BEAM DYNAMICS", second sentence: "Allowing beam dynamics..." should be replaced by "This code allows beam dynamics..." and in the same sentence, "... the magnetic elements toward the beam lines..." can be change to "... the magnetic elements of the beam lines...".
In section "BEAM POSITION MONITOR" in the sentence below Eq. (2) "...N Protons number in the Bd distribution..." may be replaced by "...N Proton number in the bunch distribution..."
In section "BEAM POSITION MONITOR" , third page, last sentence of the first column, there is a typo "form" should be replaced by "from".
abstract_log.editor_notes: I recommend this paper for publication. Only minor corrections, mainly due to typos, are suggested.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Effect of Electrostatic Deflectors and Fringe Fields on Spin for Hadron Electric Dipole Moment Measurements on Storage Rings
paper.abstract: The observed matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe cannot be explained by the Standard Model. An explanation is a non-vanishing Electric Dipole Moment of subatomic particles. The JEDI (Jülich Electric Dipole moment Investigations) collaboration is preparing a direct EDM measurement of protons and deuterons first at the storage ring COSY (COoler SYnchrotron) and later at a dedicated storage ring. To achieve this, one needs a stable polarization, i.e. around 1000 seconds for spin coherence time. One source of decoherence are the electrostatic deflectors, and this must be quantified. We developed an analytical model for cylindrical deflectors, including fringe fields, and the associated beam and spin transfer functions, integrated over the deflector. All boundaries (including ground) are considered, giving a realistic, accurate field map up to any order. We get universal formulas, the only adjustable parameter being the deflector gap/radius ratio, all other terms being numerical. This has been implemented in BMAD. We present the mathematical, physical and numerical developments, as well as results for a proton storage ring.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Development of a Beam Loss Monitor and Transverse Beam Dynamics Studies at ARRONAX C70XP Cyclotron
paper.abstract: The ARRONAX Interest Public Group uses a multi-particle, high energy and high intensity industrial accelerator which has several beamlines used for various purposes. For improvement of operations, ARRONAX has foster and installed robust air-based Beam Loss Monitors (BLMs) outside the beam pipes. BLMs consist of four active detecting plates and are integrated within the experimental physics and industrial control system (EPICS) monitoring and data acquisition system. Each BLM has been tested for the pre-commissioning phase with beams at low intensity (600pA to 6nA on target). Comparative studies and selection of the BLMs has led to their installation at high intensity beam lines. BLMs are now used in beam dynamics studies to investigate transverse characteristics while in regular operation. They support present and future operations extension foreseen at ARRONAX. The results from experimental studies on BLMs at low beam intensity and status of beam dynamics studies at high intensity (A) are presented here. Keywords: BLM, beam dynamics, EPICS, Gas ionization detector, cyclotron, proton.
paper.agency: "Investissements d'Avenir", Equipex Arronax-Plus, Institute of Nuclear and Particle Physics from the National Scientific Research center (CNRS) and the Regional Council of Pays de la Loire, France.
paper.footnote: *F. Poirier, S. Girault, STUDIES AND UPGRADES ON THE C70 CYCLOTRON ARRONAX, Proceedings of Cyclotrons 2016, Zurich, Switzerland

abstract_log.comments:
First, let me mention that there is no PDF version of this paper, only a latex source file that does not compile. I tried to fix the bugs that latex threw up (mis-matched brackets, incorrect file names, formatting errors), but gave up and ended up just looking at the raw latex file and jpeg files. This means I cannot make heads or tails of tables, for example. For reviewing, there should be a PDF version available.
The technology presented seems very straightforward, air ionization beam loss monitors which are arranged around a beam pipe, though this is actually not clearly explained. According to the paper, the BLMs have been used at low-intensity beam lines, and are now being tested at high-intensity beam lines, with some results from quadrupole current scans and measurements of the resulting distribution of beam losses around the beam pipe downstream.
It is not clear what is original about this, though it seems to be useful as far as it goes. However, the whole setup is not explained very well at all. For example, a PMT is used as an intensity monitor to calibrate the BLMs, but what is the PMT looking at? Is there a scintillator in front of it, or is it measuring air ionization or transition radiation or something? This is not explained as far as I can see.
The graphs showing the quadrupole scans are hard to read, with the horizontal axis labels being placed in the middle of the graph, and hence buried under data lines quite often. A more traditional graph layout and presentation style would be appreciated. Also, the axis labels have confusing units on them. For example, "Local beam size in plane at collimator (uA)." Why are the units of size uA? I suppose this is supposed to be the sum of currents of opposing BLM channels, and hence some kind of measure of beam tails that escaped the beam pipe or something, but this needs to be explained. And "Beam positioning in a plane at collimator" has no units at all. Is this a measurement of differential losses or something? Not explained. In any case, using BLMs as BPMs is a very crude approach to beam monitoring, though there may be practical reasons for it that are not explained.
Also, because I cannot see what the formatted paper looks like, I cannot get a proper feel for its length, but just from looking at the text file, it seems rather short and perfunctory. It needs a lot more exposition to really explain what is going on.
Regrettably, I cannot recommend publishing this as a "reviewed" paper in the current state.

abstract_log.log_status: 3) Is some aspect or part of the work original or demonstrate clear progress?
4) Is the presentation of methods, results and conclusion understandable?

abstract_log.comments: According to the guidelines, I don¿t think the paper in current form can be accepted. The reason is as below. 1. No previous BLM works were referenced. 2. The references are not in good order and not referenced when it appeared in the first time. e.g. G4 simulation. 3. In both QD scan figures, (figure 6 and 7). You see a loop back of the curves, which indicates each quadrupole setting could have two positions or sizes value. If multiple experiments were done in each setting, better way to present would be data and error bar. There is no explanation of what the meaning of the curves with different colour is. 4. In figure 5, horizontal axis labels are missing. 5. In figure 2, Red underline in the word of `Beamline¿? Is this mean anything? In the text in the previous paragraph, it says `a "Harmattan R928" photomultiplier detector, used as a proton beam intensity monitoring reference¿, which is not shown in the figure 2. Is it the light detector? 6. 4-finger, fingers mentioned in many paragraphs, are they meaning the plates of the BLM? It is not very clear. You should have a paragraph to explain the BLM assembly. 7. In the paragraph under the title `Quadrupole scan studies.¿ Change to `Transverse beam dynamics studies, here used "Quadrupole gradient modulation[6] (quad scan)" technique. Measurements that are done at the collimator and BLM level are used to study beam focal point, local beam size and beam centroid.¿ Next sentence, `By adding and subtracting two opposite facing fingers¿, what signal were added and subtracted, not clear. 8. Next paragraph. `Non centred¿ to `off centred`, `kicks with¿ kicked by¿. How does stripper foil azimuthal location help to mitigate beam centering? 9. `At 10μA, the quad scans are more secure from the point of view of vacuum¿ what do you mean by secure?

abstract_log.comments:
I am approving this, but recommend a number of corrections if possible. (Let me add that I would very much like to encourage the development of medical accelerator technologies, so offer these corrections in a constructive spirit.)
The PMT could use explanation. Is the PMT looking at light from a scintillator (what kind?) placed in the way of the beam? Also, what is the structure of the instrumented beam dump? Is it a Faraday cup?
Fig 3: Overlaying image of BLM on the horizontal axis does not look professional. Perhaps slide BLM image down below graph so it does not overlap. The axes should be clearly visible, and axis labels OUTSIDE the axes.
Fig 4: The hole in the wall where the beam pipe passes through should be made more visually clear.
Fig 5: Horizontal axis needs label. Maybe separate out the x and y data into separate histograms, otherwise binning looks funny.
Also, vertical axis units should be "counts," not "count." Or perhaps "events."
Figs 6 and 7: X-axis labels should be at the bottom of the graph. Vertical axis labels should be changed -- positions and sizes do not come in units of $\mu$A. Perhaps labelling them as "Sum of opposite finger signals ($\mu$A)" and "Difference of opposite finger signals ($\mu$A)," or something similar, would work. The text explains how these quantities are used as proxies for size and position.
Title of Fig 6 should be above graph, not inside.
Optional: Figs 7 a) and b) might want titles something like "Beam size changes as function of quadrupole current" and "Beam position changes...". Those titles, combined with the (fixed) axis labels, should make the contents quickly comprehensible independently of the main text.
Are there no BPMs? A brief mention of this would suffice, and perhaps help further motivate the use of BLMs for beam optics studies (in addition to machine protection purposes).
Some general reference to BLM designs by others would be considered good form.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Spin Decoherence in the Frozen Spin Storage Ring Method of Search for a Particle EDM
paper.abstract: Spin coherence refers to a measure of preservation of polarization in an initially polarized beam. The spin vector of a particle injected into a storage ring starts to precess about the vertical magnetic field vector in accordance with the Thomas-BMT equation. The precession frequency is dependent on the equilibrium-level energy, which differs across the beam particles. This does not pose a problem when the initial polarization is vertical; however, the Frozen Spin Storage Ring EDM search method [*] requires beam polarization along the momentum vector, i.e., in the horizontal plane. In the present work we analyze the source of decoherence, and investigate the way it can be suppressed in the horizontal plane in a perfectly aligned ring by means of sextupole fields. We also consider the case of an imperfect ring: transference of decoherence into the vertical plane induced by vertical plane spin precession, and the effect of sextupole fields.
paper.footnote: * D. Anastassopoulos et al. AGS Proposal: Search for a permanent electric dipole moment of the deuteron nucleus at the 10 −29 e · cm level. BNL report, 2008.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Tune and Chromaticity Optimization at Bessy II for the Transverse Resonant Island Bucket Optics
paper.abstract: Transverse Resonant Island Buckets (TRIBs *) correspond to a second stable orbit, longitudinally winding around the core orbit in the transverse $x$-$x^{\prime}$-phasespace. The exploitation possibilities for stable TRIBs are under investigation at the third generation light source BESSY II in Berlin. The applicability for bunch separation is a main subject of these studies. Stable operation of TRIBs optics with a single or few bunches on the second orbit and a multibunch train on the main orbit has been shown **. Photons emitted on the second orbit are well separated from those of the main orbit at all beamlines. This provides the possibility of bunch separation by beamline adjustment for the timing community without significant impact on the average brightness for other users. Simulations based on linear optics from closed orbits (LOCO) and on nonlinear optics derived from the measured chromaticity and tune shift with action (TSWA) predict this separation well. Friendly user experiments in 2018 confirmed these results. The scheduled upgrade BESSY VSR *** features simultaneously stored long and short bunches. Then TRIBs optics would in principle enable the separation of the different bunches at every beamline offering unique possibilities to our users. Simulations and measurements aiming to investigate further possible optimization of the TRIBs optics are presented.
paper.agency: Federal Ministry of Education and Research
paper.footnote: * F. Armborst, P. Goslawski et al, DOI: 10.18429/JACoW-IPAC2018-TUPML052 ** P. Goslawski, F. Armborst et al. DOI: 10.18429/JACoW-IPAC2017-WEPIK057 *** A. Jankowiak et al., DOI: 10.5442/R0001

paper.main_class: MC1: Circular and Linear Colliders
paper.sub_class: A24 Accelerators and Storage Rings, Other
paper.title: HOM Damping Options for the Z-Pole Operating Scenario of FCC-ee
paper.abstract: The Z-pole option of FCC-ee is an Ampere class machine with a beam current of 1.39 A. Due to high HOM power and strong HOM damping requirements, the present baseline of FCC-ee considers a single cell cavity at 400 MHz. In this paper, different HOM damping schemes are compared for the Z-pole operating scenario with the aim of lowering the parasitic longitudinal and transverse impedance. The HOM power for each damping scheme is also calculated.

abstract_log.comments:
Thanks for submitting an interesting paper. Below are a few comments requiring only minor corrections.
For the title, jacow accepts lower case in names where appropriate. I suggest you change FCC-EE to FCC-ee. This can be done with \NoCaseChange{FCC-ee}.
Symbols should be defined when first encountered. This is good practice even when they are commonly used symbol that readers probably already know. E.g. G, R and Q. Please check the paper to ensure all the symbols are defined.
Eq (1) is not clear. To make this clearer, the intention should be spelled out. For example, "The optimization term to be minimized is ...., where the following conditions must be met". And "the variables for this optimization are ...". This is just an example. The authors can play with the wording as they like. But at the moment the formatting is not clear or common and is not explained.
Also near Eq. (1), a reference to Fig. 1a would be useful in order to define the geometry parameters, a, b, Ri, etc.
It would be good to reference the recent CDR so reader can look up further detail. An appropriate place for this would be in the Introduction at the end of the sentence, "As a design choice, the maximum synchrotron radiation (SR) per turn for one beam is fixed to 50 MW, thus the stored beam current ranges from 1.39 A (at Z-pole) to 5.4 mA (at t¯t)."

abstract_log.comments:
I found that the paper was well written, covering an important and current topic, and that the analysis was well done.
In the section describing "SRF CAVITY DESIGN", the geometry optimization of the cavity is described, and it mentions that it uses "a genetic algorithm method implemented in the optimization toolbox of MATLAB" to find the geometry parameters minimizing the objective function, it does not say how this objective function is actually computed. I assume coupling of e.g. CST MWS to MATLAB, however this should be stated (as it is done in the later subsection "HOM power") and/or a reference given.
As a minor nit-pick, in Figure 3 the spectrum of the beam is shown on the right-hand axis, however this not mentioned in the caption of the figure. Furthermore the later part of the chapter states that the impedance spectrum was computed up to 4.1 GHz but the figure stops at 3 GHz -- why?
I recommend the paper for publication after at least the first comment has been addressed.
Thank you for the corrections, I no longer have any objections.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Simulation Studies for a EEHG seeded FEL in the XUV
paper.abstract: Echo-enabled harmonic generation (EEHG) is a promising technique for seeded free electron lasers (FELs) not only to go down to wavelengths of 4 nm, but also to simplify the schemes that are currently used to achieve a similar wavelength range (double cascade HGHG). Thus a study optimizing the EEHG performance in the wavelength range from 60 to \SI{4}{nm} has been performed. The more critical working point, at 4 nm, is here analyzed in terms of seed laser energy stability for two different seed laser frequencies: visible and UV.

abstract_log.comments: This paper describes the theory and simulation results for optimizing the EEHG performance in the wavelength down to 4 nm. By using the simulation code GENESIS1.3, the authors investigated the tolerance of the second seed laser power for VIS and UV seeds, and concluded that the VIS case was slightly more sensitive to the second seed laser power than the UV case. As authors pointed out, on the other hand, the VIS laser is more stable than UV from the view point of laser technologies. I think the paper clearly describes the authors simulation studies on the optimization of EEHG and is good to be published as a light peer review paper.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.sub_class: A24 Accelerators and Storage Rings, Other
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Applications & Operation of an Inverse Compton-Source in User Mode
paper.abstract: Synchrotron radiation in the lab? Inverse Compton scattering of infrared photons from relativistic electrons generates brilliant quasi-monochromatic X-rays with a storage ring of a few meters circumference, e.g. at the Munich Compact Light Source (MuCLS)*. The availability of synchrotron light in a laboratory enables broader access to synchrotron techniques, especially in (but not limited to) clinical imaging and preclinical biomedical applications. Since commissioning of the MuCLS, we have been exploring the latter in daily user operation. So far, the focus has been on dynamic in-vivo small animal respiratory imaging**, grating-based phase-contrast imaging, e.g. for quantitative material decomposition***, and spectroscopic imaging, e.g. for angiography****. We demonstrate significantly improved results over conventional clinical imaging as well as new ways of investigating lung disease development and treatment response. Key to performing such studies in user operation is stable X-ray beam delivery, even though the possibility for operator interventions is limited during these runs. We present our experiences of running an inverse Compton source in user mode and how we address the challenges arising with it, in particular through our system for online monitoring and active stabilization of the electron-photon interaction point.
paper.agency: We acknowledge financial support by the Centre for Advanced Laser Applications, DFG Cluster of Excellence Munich-Centre for Advanced Photonics (DFG EXC-158) and DFG Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz program.
paper.footnote: * Eggl et al., J. Sync. Rad 23, p.1137 (2016) ** Gradl et al., Sci. Rep. 8, 6788 (2018) *** Braig et al., Sci. Rep. 8, 16394 (2018) **** Kulpe et al., PLOS ONE, accepted

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: SINGLE SHOT CATHODE TRANSVERSE MOMENTUM IMAGING IN PHOTOINJECTORS
paper.abstract: In state of the art photoinjector electron sources, cathode performance determines the lower limit of achievable beam emittance. Measuring the thermal emittance at the photocathodes in electron guns is of vital importance for improving the injectors. Traditional methods, like solenoid scan, pepper-pot, need multi-shots and are time-consuming, therefore suffer from machine stability. Here we propose a new method, named cathode transverse momentum imaging. By tuning the gun solenoid focusing, the electrons' transverse momentum at the cathode is imaged to a downstream screen, which enables a single shot measurement. Several experiments have been done at the Photo Injector Test Facility at DESY in Zeuthen (PITZ) with a Cs2Te cathode. Measurements of cathode transverse momentum, the corresponding spectra, cathode transverse momentum map and its correlation with surface electric field are presented.

paper.main_class: MC5: Beam Dynamics and EM Fields
paper.sub_class: D11 Code Developments and Simulation Techniques
paper.title: Synchrotron Radiation Reflections in the CLIC Beam Delivery System
paper.abstract: Synchrotron radiation (SR) reflection is an important issue for future linear colliders. High fluxes of the SR might impact the performance of the detector, through irradiation of the forward luminosity and beam quality calorimeters or of the innermost layers of the vertex detector. The photon reflections depend on the beam pipe apertures' size, their shape, and materials used with various surface roughness. In this work, we present a study of SR including reflection for the 380 GeV and 3 TeV beam parameters and optics of the Compact Linear Collider's Final Focus System. The simulations of the SR reflections using the Synrad+ software are presented and the impact on the detector is discussed.

The transverse position distribution plot for 3 TeV beam is missing ¿ add, please. Some minor changes are suggested: - Fig. 1: Add label to horizontal axis. Add labels to each BDS section (e.g. you could use brackets to delimit the FFS section) and relevant components (IP, QD0). Increase font size. - Quote in text the distance between QD0 and IP. - Replace: ¿might cause performance deterioration¿ by ¿might deteriorate performance¿. - ¿The photons used in this study are produced in the FFS and have an energy in the range from 1 keV to 30 keV are studied.¿ - ¿No photon emitted in the last 20 m can cause a hit in the detector.¿ I assume this is not by chance, but by design ¿ add reference to design. - Add sentence to highlight required orientation of the saw-tooth profile w.r.t. beam direction. - ¿Photons with ¿ emitted in the last beanding and quadrupole magnets¿: add explanation of this statement: 1) we can conclude this because distribution is not material dependent and because angle is too shallow to allow reflection in 770 meter-long FFS. - ¿The larger increase in ¿is smoother¿: add sentence saying: comparison of Fig. 3 (380 GeV) and Fig. 4 (3 TeV). - Detailed detector simulation study is mentioned. paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Vertical Beam Size Measurement Methods at the BESSY II Storage Ring and their Resolution Limits
paper.abstract: With the VSR upgrade for the BESSY II electron storage ring* bunch resolved diagnostics are required for machine commissioning and to ensure the long-term quality and stability of operation. For transverse beam size measurements we are going to use an interferometric method, which will be combined with a fast gated intensified CCD camera at a subsequent stage. A double-slit interferometer method has already been verified successfully at BESSY II**. In addition first 2D bunch resolved measurement tests have been performed at the dedicated diagnostics beamline for bunch length measurements. Measurements of the interferometer and X-ray pinholes as function of a vertical electron beam excitation are compared in this paper.
paper.footnote: * A. Jankowiak et al., Germany, June 2015. DOI: 10.5442/R0001 ** M. Koopmans et al., in Proc. IPAC'17, paper MOPAB032, 2017

abstract_log.comments: Dear author, thank you for your submission. Editor found a small number of formatting issues. So the following changes have been made to the source of the paper to conform to the JACoW template. # FC06 LaTeX formatting: too much negative vertical spacing, overlay of graphic in Fig. 5 over last line of text in the preceding paragraph. # FC06 LaTeX formatting: the extensive use of "%" to bind everything together and makes it harder for TeX to place vertical space and glue, and you have to compensate by placing \\ and \indent to accomplish a simple page break like an empty line in the source # TC02 changed "Tab." to "Table" (Table is never abbreviated) # TC03 Table formatting incorrect: table captions have to be in Initial Caps, no period # TC03 Table parameter: Bold Math (\bm{}) font used to set bold in table parameter row # TC06 Reference formatting: wrong quotation marks: closing instead of opening for [1-7, 9, 10] # TC06 Reference formatting: the use of DOIs is encouraged (4 added). please use the Reference Search tool to resolve all JACoW conferences: https://ref.ipac19.org/ Please log into your SPMS account, download the PDF file and check the paper for the changes made (and look for editor introduced errors) and when you agree with the changes put it to GREEN via the offered link otherwise reject the changes and give a comment please.
Poster Posted, Poster Manned, Poster Satisfactory.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Current Status of the MYRRHA Cavities
paper.abstract: The MYRRHA (Multi-purpose hYbrid Research Reac-tor for High-tech Applications) Project is a planned ac-celerator driven system (ADS) for the transmutation of long-living radioactive waste. In order test the reliability of the planned 17 MeV injector, a shortened injector with 5.9 MeV consisting of the ion source, a 4-Rod RFQ, 2 Quarter Wave Rebunchers (QWRs) and a total of 7 normal conducting CH structures is currently being installed in Louvein-la-Neuve (LLN, Belgium). Before the cavities can be tested with beam, they are subjected to so-called low power tests several times during the individual con-struction stages in order to be able to correct any devia-tions. This paper describes the status of the two Quarter Wave Rebunchers, which are currently in the process of copper plating and final acceptance, as well as the first two CH structures, the first of which is already being conditioned while CH 2 is still in preparation.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Conditioning of the Frontline Cavities of the MYRRHA Injector
paper.abstract: The MYRRHA Project (Multi-purpose hYbrid Research Reactor for High-tech Applications) in Mol, Belgium, is an upcoming accelerator driven system (ADS) for the transmutation of long-living radioactive waste. In the injector section of the accelerator, consisting of a 4-rod RFQ and a normal conducting CH-cavity section, the protons will be accelerated up to 17 MeV before entering the superconducting gap-spoke cavity section with an output energy of 600 MeV. A shortened test-injector with an output energy of 5.9 MeV is currently being installed at the SCK.CEN in Louvein-la- Neuve, Belgium. This test-injector serves the purpose of testing the reliability of the planned injector. When commissioning a cavity, it first has to be fed very little power to avoid damage to the structure by flashovers, discharges and multipacting. The power is then slowly increased up to full operation level. In this process, the surfaces are cleaned by heating/outgasing so that the effects disturbing operation described above do no longer occur. This paper will report on the status of the conditioning of the 176.1 MHz 4-rod RFQ up to 120 kW of the MYRRHA-injector and additional measurements concerning the gap voltage which are currently being performed at the SCK.CEN.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Collimation of Target Induced Halo Following MAGIX at MESA
paper.abstract: The Mainz Energy-recovering Superconducting Accelerator (MESA) will be an electron accelerator allowing operation in energy-recovery linac (ERL) mode. It provides the opportunity to operate scattering experiments at energies of ~100 MeV with thin gas-targets. The MESA Internal Gas Target Experiment (MAGIX) aims to operate windowless jet targets and different gases up to Xenon to search for possible dark photon interactions, to precisely measure the magnetic proton radius and astrophysical S-factors. Investigations on the impact of the target on beam dynamics and beam losses are required for machine safety and to examine limits to ERL operation. The goal of this work is to understand target induced halo in the different experimental setups, track halo particles through downstream sections to examine beam losses and include a suitable collimation system and shielding into the accelerator layout to protect the machine from direct and indirect damage through beam losses and radiation. The present status of the investigations is presented.
paper.agency: Supported by the DFG through GRK 2128

abstract_log.comments:
This paper presents the simulation results of collimating beam halo for an ERL. Such a study has an important and practical value for an operational facility. The halo studied in this paper is generated by the interaction between a beam and a windowless gas jet, and then prorogates along the downstream transport line. Mainly two simulation codes, i.e. Geant4 and BDSIM, were used to implement a two-stage tracking simulation to define needed collimation. Although I believe this work is important and the result will benefit the facility, this paper needs more details to claim its scientific significance. My detailed comments are listed below:
(1) Even the title claims that it is a ¿beam dynamics¿ study, authors didn¿t use any beam dynamics theory, or at least explicitly mentioned it in this paper. I tracked back to the ref. [3], in which authors explained the gas density and the Gaussian beam sizes at the interaction point. Then two reliable simulation codes had been used for identifying the distribution of beam loss along the downstream beamline. Based on the distribution, the collimation system was specified. It is a standard must-do procedure, and every facility did in a similar way. This paper could be an important internal tech-note rather than a journal publication.
(2) The conclusion mentioned ¿severe nonlinear beam dynamical behavior¿. Since there is no nonlinear magnet in the beamline, the nonlinearity originates from the beam-target interaction, then it could be amplified when the halo passes through the chamber or magnet yokes. Therefore, the beam/gas actual initial distribution is critical. But they are the assumptions (based on their design?) when the simulation was set up. Therefore, this conclusion might not be so convincing. For example, if the beam profile is different from a Gaussian distribution, or its Twiss functions are distorted, will the performance of this system degrade?
(3) One thing maybe makes the paper to be unique (deserving to be published as a light peer-reviewed one) is that the collimation actually is realized by a two-stage procedure. First, a highly-dense halo is widened by a pre-collimation spreader, then absorbed by the next collimators. To emphasize that, an optimal pre/post-collimation configuration needs to be explored, not only the thickness but their locations, material as well. The methodology of design of the collimation system is needed.
In summary, no new theory, tool, and method had been developed in this paper. The scientific significance is not obvious for readers.
abstract_log.editor_notes: Although this study is critically important, its originality is not strong enough. They were using existing tools and methods to accomplish a must-do project. No new theory, tools (such as a better simulation code), method (such as optimization of a collimation system) had been developed. I would like to suggest a major revision before it can be accepted. But I doubt if authors can do it within a tight timeframe.

abstract_log.comments: The paper is in good shape with all requirements satisfied. There are a few comments and suggestions to the authors. First, why use Be as the material could be further clarified. Secondly, it will be nice to include actual measured beam loss data, if possible, for follow-up work. Thirdly, the Fig.5 is a little bit misleading with the "ratio", because the denominator might be a small number. The authors might want to consider a better way to present the collimation improvement other than just simple ratio.
abstract_log.editor_notes: The only content issue is that the Fig.5 might be a bit of misleading while interpreting the collimation improvement. Other than this minor issue, the paper is in good quality and I recommend it to be accepted.

abstract_log.comments: The revised version eliminated the obvious inconsistency between the title (the summary) and its content. The collimation system is critically important for a facility for machine protection purpose. Staged collimation including a pre-collimator, the main collimator, and a post-collimator should be robust based on the detailed simulation. As the work has been accomplished by a student, I suggest to accept it for publication.

institute.full_name: National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center

paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.sub_class: T31 Subsystems, Technology and Components, Other
paper.title: Further Designs of HOM Couplers for Superconducting 400 MHz RF Cavities
paper.abstract: The Future Circular Collider (FCC) is one possible future successor of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. The proton-proton collider center-of-mass collision energy is set to 100 TeV with a beam current of 0.5 A. To achieve this energy a stable acceleration is critical and therefore higher order modes (HOM) need to be damped. HOM dampers, further characterized as couplers, need to fulfill several criteria to be efficient. As a first property the couplers should assure a longitudinal impedance of higher order modes of below 10 kW. Furthermore, the loaded Q-factor should be below 1000 and the corresponding R/Q value should be in the range of 10 Ω. Besides the Hook-type and Probe-type HOM coupler two additional designs were simulated. The recent results of the different couplers attached to a superconducting 400 MHz RF cavity will be presented.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Search for Electric Dipole Moments at Cosy in Jülich - Spin-Tracking Simulations Using Bmad
paper.abstract: The observed matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe cannot be explained by the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. In order to resolve the matter dominance an additional CP violating phenomenon is needed. A candidate for physics beyond the SM is a non-vanishing Electric Dipole Moment (EDM) of subatomic particles. Since permanent EDMs violate parity and time reversal symmetries, they are also CP violating if the CPT -theorem is assumed. The JEDI (Jülich Electric Dipole moment Investigations) collaboration in Jülich is preparing a direct EDM measurement of protons and deuterons first at the storage ring COSY (COoler SYnchrotron) and later at a dedicated storage ring. In order to analyse the data and to disentangle the EDM signal from systematic effects spin tracking simulations are needed. Therefore a model of COSY was implemented using the software library Bmad. It includes the measured magnet misalignments of the latest survey and a simplified description of the RF-Wien Filter device that is used for the EDM measurement. The model was successfully benchmarked using analytical predictions of the spin behavior. A crucial point regarding the data analysis is the knowledge of the orientation of the invariant spin axis with vanishing EDM at the position of the RF-Wien Filter. Especially its radial component is unknown and spin tracking simulations can be used to determine this missing number. Tracking results as well as the algorithm to find the invariant spin axis will be presented.

abstract_log.comments:
This paper well describes the comparison of two derivative-free algorithms for beamline optimization. These method are very valuable because they can be used for many other accelerator application, for example cavity parameter optimization. To increase the quality of the paper, let me suggest some points.
It is better to declare that the authors conducted the comparison of two algorithms, BOBYQA and Bayesian, in INTRODUCTION.
It is better to minimize the general description of derivative-free algorithms, instead, the example of such as loss budget and beam profile at the target before and after the optimization should be shown.
In Figure1, there are asymmetry in Ex, for example at near s=75. Are there any reason?
In the subsection ¿BOBYQA optimization¿, the Powell¿s conjugate direction method is older but appear later. It is somehow confusing. ¿Often these traditional optimization algorithms are not often robustness against noise.¿ Only one often is sufficient?
In the subsection ¿Bayesian optimization¿, there is a phrase ¿Two major assumption¿, but it is not so clear the first assumption is what and the second assumption is what.
There are several ¿has been carry out¿, should be ¿has been carried out¿.
There are several wrong usage of singular and plural forms.
In section ¿OPTIMIZATION OF HADES BEAM LINE¿, reference of MADX should be shown. In the second paragraph, ¿only a part of the beam line elements¿, how much elements? ¿This has been sufficient¿, it is better to clarify the reason why it is regarded as sufficient. It is not necessary ¿from [15]¿ and ¿from [12], it already shown in previous section. How much time to optimize? The actual time is very important for online optimization.
In conclusion, last sentence, why the author think Bayesian is better?

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Advanced Beam Dynamics Design for the Superconducting Heavy Ion Accelerator HELIAC
paper.abstract: The standalone superconducting (SC) continuous wave (CW) heavy ion linac HELIAC (HElmholtz LInear ACcelerator) is a common project of GSI and HIM under key support of IAP Frankfurt and in collaboration with Moscow Engineering Physics Institute (MEPhI) and Moscow Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics (KI-ITEP). It is intended for future experiments with heavy ions near the Coulomb barrier within super-heavy element (SHE) research and aims at developing a linac with multiple CH cavities as key components downstream the High Charge State Injector (HLI) at GSI. The design is challenging due to the requirement of intense beams in CW mode up to a mass-to-charge ratio of 6, while covering a broad output energy range from 3.5 to 7.3 MeV/u with minimum energy spread. In 2017 the first superconducting section of the linac has been successfully commissioned and extensively tested with beam at GSI. In the light of experience gained in this research so far, the beam dynamics layout for the entire linac has recently been updated and optimized with particular emphasis on realistic assumptions of cavity gap and drift lengths as well as gap voltage distributions for CH3¿CH11.
paper.agency: Work supported by BMBF contr. No. 05P18RFRB1, EU Framework Programme H2020 662186 (MYRTE) and HIC for FAIR

abstract_log.comments:
This paper aims to report the progress of the advanced beam dynamics of HELIAC. Unfortunately, it's not clear the real progress here over the previous papers by the authors. Overall, it seems pretty similar to that with author's recently published IPAC18 paper. The new efforts and progress highlights should be clearly mentioned at the beginning. At first, I will point some technical issues. 1. The abstract is a bit long, especially the former half. 2. The abstract (may be conclusion too) should not include any citations. 3. The references are extremely long. Should be optimized and the reference section can be moved to the extra page as the manuscript certainly needs more explanations. The paper also should have somehow standalone content. 4. The figure sizes, axis labels are small. Almost no explanations of the figures in the text. Always written as "see Figxx". 5. The table 1 should contain some more important parameters, such as beam emittances, etc. 6. Some of the acronyms were nor expanded.
Here are few more recommendation/questions that the author should also consider. 7. The paper needs more scientific explanations for the concept of advanced beam dynamics design, simulations procedures and the scientific significance of the obtained results. 8. It seems to me that the work needs error studies to demonstrate an advancement here over the past works. Also required to make sure that can keep the required beam parameters or not. 9. What is purpose of showing Fig.2 and relation of CST studio simulation to this work. The simulation condition and/or references should be mentioned. 10. What are the reasons for the emittance growth? How the transverse emittance growth improved from that of reported in ref[7]? 11. What are the possible errors should be considered and is it possible to keep the energy spread within +-3 keV/u by considering all possible errors?
abstract_log.editor_notes:
In general, the paper has some technical issues. For example, citations in the abstract and conclusion. The number of citations are too many. It's hard for the readers to look all the references. The paper seems pretty much similar to those with author's earlier papers. The new efforts and progress highlights should be clearly mentioned. In this sense, the error studies simulation results should be included.
Also, the paper needs more scientific explanations for the concept of present advanced beam dynamics, simulation procedures and the scientific significance of the results. The present level of paper may be better for conference proceedings itself.

abstract_log.comments:
It isn't immediately obvious to this reviewer what is 'advanced' about the beam dynamics. While high gradient and low emittance growth is shown in the simulations this is true for many different linac designs. The EQUUS concept has been around since 2009 (as the paper states) and is a variation of KONUS. Both methods can result in good designs in certain applications but does this alone really deserve the term 'advanced'? The authors have certainly found a nice beam dynamics solution but only by applying (and perhaps refining) existing techniques.
Apart from this small point the paper is of sufficient quality and interest for publication in conference proceedings. There are rather a lot of references, space which could be used for additional technical information, but not to the point where I would reject the submission.

paper.main_class: MC5: Beam Dynamics and EM Fields
paper.sub_class: D05 Coherent and Incoherent Instabilities - Theory, Simulations, Code Developments
paper.title: Beam Breakup Simulations for the Mainz Energy Recovering Superconducting Accelerator MESA
paper.abstract: MESA is a two pass energy recovery linac (ERL) currently under construction at the Johannes Gutenberg-University in Mainz. MESA uses four 1.3 GHz TESLA type cavities with 12.5 MV/m of accelerating gradient in two modified ELBE type cryomodule with improved thermal connection of the HOM antennas and cw operation. In the first stage of MESA operation 1mA of beam current is foreseen, which will later be upgraded to 10mA. One potential limit to maximum beam current in ERLs is the transverse beam breakup (BBU) instability induced by dipole Higher Order Modes (HOMs). These modes can be excited by bunches passing through the cavities off axis. Following bunches are then deflected by the HOMs, which results in even larger offsets for recirculated bunches. This feedback can even lead to beam loss. Simulation results for HOM spectra of a single TESLA cavity are available for example in *. It was possible to measure the HOM spectra in the cold, not tuned cavities at DESY and in the cold string tuned to the 1.3 GHz fundamental mode at Mainz. Results for the maximum beam current for MESA, limited by BBU, for the various HOM spectra are presented.
paper.agency: This work is supported by DFG through PRISMA+ cluster of excellence EXC 2118/2019, RTG 2128 and by the European Union's Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation programme under Grant Agreement No 730871.
paper.footnote: * "Eigenmode Calculations for the TESLA Cavity Considering Wave-Propagation Losses through Fundamental and Higher-Order Mode Couplers", W. Ackermann, H. De Gersem, C. Liu, and T. Weiland

abstract_log.comments: Dear author, thank you for your submission. Editor found a number of formatting issues with the bibliography. So the following changes have been made to the source of the paper and the bib file source to conform to the JACoW template. # TC04 Figure reference formatting: (References to) Fig./Figure are always written with a Capital "F", to Table(s) with a Capital "T", to Eq(s)./Equation(s) with a Capital "E"] in addition: "fig" => "Fig." # FC06 LaTeX: Bib entries corrected "Doi" shouldn't have "https://doi.org/"; "Booktitle" corrected to the abbreviated form + location, and date shouldn't appear; all other settings controlled with \AtEveryBibitem{) and \clear... for specific fields/lists in the bibliography. # FC06 LaTeX: \center is not a valid command, use \centering Please log into your SPMS account, download the PDF file and check the paper for the changes made (and look for editor introduced errors) and when you agree with the changes put it to GREEN via the offered link otherwise reject the changes and give a comment please.
Cancelled indentation at the line below second equation in page 2.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Beam-based Alignment at the Cooler Syncrotron (COSY)
paper.abstract: There is a matter-antimatter asymmetry observed in the universe that can not be explained by the Standard Model of particle physics. To resolve that problem additional CP violating phenomena are needed. A candidate for an additional CP violating phenomenon is a non-vanishing Electric Dipole Moment (EDM) of subatomic particles. Since permanent EDMs violate parity and time reversal symmetries, they also violate CP if the CPT-theorem holds. The Jülich Electric Dipole moment Investigation (JEDI) Collaboration works on a direct measurement of the electric dipole moment (EDM) of protons and deuterons using a storage ring. The JEDI experiment requires a small beam orbit RMS in order to measure the EDM. Therefore an ongoing upgrade of the Cooler Syncrotron (COSY) is done in order to improve the precision of the beam position. One of part of this upgrade is to determine the magnetic center of the quadrupoles with respect to the beam position monitors. This can be done with the so called beam-based alignment method. The first results of the beam-based alignment measurement performed in February 2019 will be presented.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Study for the Alignment of Focusing Solenoid of ARES RF Gun and Effect of Misalignment of Solenoid on Emittance of Space Charge Dominated Electron Beam
paper.abstract: SINBAD (Short and INnovative Bunches and Accelerators at DESY) facility will host multiple experiments relating to ultra-short high brightness beams and novel experiments with ultra-high gradient. ARES (Accelerator Research Experiment at SINBAD) Linac is an S-band photo injector to produce such electron bunches at around 100 MeV. The Linac will be commissioned in stages with the first stage corresponding to gun commissioning. In this paper, we present studies about the scheme adopted for the alignment of focusing solenoid for the ARES gun. The method is bench marked using ASTRA simulations. Moreover the effect of misalignment of the solenoid on the emittance of space charge dominated scheme and its compensation is also discussed.

paper.main_class: MC5: Beam Dynamics and EM Fields
paper.title: Preliminary Lattice Studies for the Single-Invariant Optics Experiment at the University of Maryland
paper.abstract: A novel approach to transverse resonance suppression in next generation high-intensity accelerators is the use of nonlinear optical elements to induce large tune spreads which result in reduced responses to resonance driving perturbations*. In order to test this theory, we have built and characterized an octupole channel insert for use in the University of Maryland Electron Ring (UMER). This paper presents experimental lattice studies using a low space-charge intensity beam at an energy of 10keV with a beam current of ~150uA, tune depression < 0.005, and unnormalized RMS emittance of 4.3 mm-mr. We apply beam based measurement techniques in order to evaluate the quality of our single-invariant lattice and better understand the nonlinearities created by the octupole channel.
paper.agency: This work is supported through DOE-HEP Award DESC0010301 and NSF Award PHY1414681.
paper.footnote: * V. Danilov and S. Nagaitsev, Nonlinear accelerator lattices with one and two analytic invariants, PRSTAB, 13, 084002, 2010.

abstract_log.comments: Dear author, thank you for your submission. Editor found a number of formatting issues and the references were sloppy formatted. So the following changes have been made to the source of the paper to conform to the JACoW template. # TC01 Title formatting: no period after Title # TC03 Table formatting wrong: caption below table # TC03 Table 1 formatting incorrect: table too wide (over outside margin), width adjusted using \setlength\tabcolsep{4pt}. Please check margins using jacow class file option "boxit" # TC03 Table formatting incorrect: table captions have to be in Initial Caps, no period; longer captions have the first sentence in Initial Caps # TC04 Figure reference formatting: (References to) Fig./Figure are always written with a Capital "F", to Table(s) with a Capital "T", to Eq(s)./Equation(s) with a Capital "E"] in addition: "fig" => "Fig." # TC06 Reference formatting: the entries of the reference section do not follow the JACoW (ieeetran) standard. please check the detailed examples in Annex B of the JACoW template (Mar 2019) how the references should be formatted and what they should contain (vol., no., pp., or DOI!) # TC06 Reference formatting: titles are typeset in curly quotation marks # TC06 Reference formatting: "Proc. <conference>", journal names and "et al." should be typeset in italics # TC06 Reference formatting: PRSTAB => Phys. Rev. ST Accel. Beams # TC06 Reference formatting: hyphenation character in [7] # TC06 Reference formatting: DOIs added for [1,5-8] # TC12 Wrong Unit: 150uA => 150\,µA Please log into your SPMS account, download the PDF file and check the paper for the changes made (and look for editor introduced errors) and when you agree with the changes put it to GREEN via the offered link otherwise reject the changes and give a comment please.

Referring to #TC04 Figure reference formatting: (References to) Fig./Figure are always written with a Capital "F", to Table(s) with a Capital "T", to Eq(s)./Equation(s) with a Capital "E"] in addition: "fig" => "Fig."
Using ctrl-f, there are still a lot of places in my paper where I refer to things as "fig" and "table" instead of "Fig" and "Table". Am I suppose to go in and change that? Or will the editor do that?
Also thank you for fixing all my mistakes.

Dear Levon, this was an obvious case of "editor got interrupted, came back, and uploaded a half finished session". As I note down problems of a paper while inspecting it, this doesn't necessarily mean that I have corrected everything :-( Sorry for the half-finished paper. I've uploaded the corrected version now, please check it again. All the best, Volker

paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.title: Understanding and Pushing the Limits of Nitrogen Doping
paper.abstract: This work will describe Fermilab experiments that focus on the optimization of doping parameters to achieve low sensitivity to trapped magnetic flux while maintaining very high Q characteristic of nitrogen doped cavities and same or higher quench fields. Working partially in the context of LCLS-2 higher energy upgrade, new doping recipes are pursued and have been found to vary the mean free path of the resonator which is related to the sensitivity to trapped magnetic flux. Moreover, a correlation has been found between lighter doping and higher quench fields while maintaining sufficiently low surface resistance.

paper.main_class: MC5: Beam Dynamics and EM Fields
paper.sub_class: D01 Beam Optics - Lattices, Correction Schemes, Transport
paper.title: The ESR Closed Orbit Calculation and Simulation
paper.abstract: The commissioning of the ESR with a new control system based on the LSA (LHC System Architecture) has started recently. This new control system is under development and considers all aspects of the expected functionality to operate the GSI/FAIR accelerators and incorporates the present GSI controls infrastructure*. Two years ago, the old control system which was based on outdated computers and operating system, was discontinued. So, both the heavy ion synchrotron SIS-18 and the Experimental Storage Ring (ESR) operation from now on have to be performed with the new FAIR control system. In order to introduce an improved model to the control system change, new calculations and simulations for SIS and ESR are necessary. In this paper we summarize the results of closed orbit calculations for the ESR which are done with three different codes, namely: ELEGANT*, MAD-X and MIRKO. Also, because the results of ELEGANT and MAD-X in this issue are similar to each other, we present ELEGANT results in the report.
paper.footnote: * R. Bär, DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW CONTROL SYSTEM FOR THE FAIR ACCELERATOR COMPLEX AT GSI. Kobe. ** Borland, M., elegant: A Flexible SDDS-Compliant Code for Accelerator Simulation.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.sub_class: A24 Accelerators and Storage Rings, Other
paper.title: BEAM DYNAMICS OF HIGH CHROMATICITY LATTICE FOR IRANIAN LIGHT SOURCE FACILITY (ILSF) STORAGE RING
paper.abstract: One of the limiting factors of electron beam lifetime in low emittance storage rings is Head-Tail (HT) insta-bility. Low emittance storage rings typically have a large negative natural chromaticity due to the strong quadru-poles. Above transition large negative natural chroma-ticity leads to large Head-Tail instability which limit the beam lifetime. Since the threshold current of HT insta-bility is directly related to linear chromaticity, increasing the linear chromaticity to slightly positive value is a solution to prevent HT instability. In this paper we in-creased the chromaticity of Iranian Light Source Facility (ILSF) to (+4, +4) and we will investigate the beam dy-namics of ILSF 3GeV storage ring in high chromaticity. For reaching this aim we have used two families of sex-tupoles for chromaticity correction and then optimized them to maximize the dynamic aperture and Touschek lifetime. The beam dynamics of high chromaticity lattice is presented in this paper.

paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.sub_class: T31 Subsystems, Technology and Components, Other
paper.title: Design of Beam Position Monitoring System for IPM Low Energy Electron LINAC
paper.abstract: A beam position monitor (BPM) is a common device used in particle accelerators to measure the position of a beam of charged-particles. The goal of this project is to simulate and build prototype of different parts to be used for IPM low energy electron Linac being developed at Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences. The IPM low energy electron Linac will initially be operated at a 7𝜇sec pulse duration and 250 Hz repetition rate with 2.998 GHz bunching frequency. A 4.5-MeV electron beam will be available in the second phase of commissioning. The device is composed of two pickup S-band cavities and a detection circuit to read out the electron beam's position. The electrode pickup sensors will sense the mode strength generated by the passing beam of electrons. The working modes are TM110 (dipole) for the so called position cavity and TM010 (monopole) for the reference cavity. When the beam crosses the two cavity gaps it induces signals proportional to the product of charge and position offset in the position cavity, and to the charge only in the reference cavity. the position cavity has four rectangular waveguides that couple to the dipole mode while rejecting the monopole mode that would otherwise limit the resolution of the electronics. This signal will be input to a detection circuit that will be used to calculate the signals detected by four antennas arranged. A 180 degree hybrid at the first stage reduce the monopole and a heterodyne receiver principle was used to down-convert the signal frequency in about MHz IF frequency. These signals can then be used to determine the beam's displacement from the center.

paper.title: Feasibility Study on Mo-99 Production Using Hybrid Method Based on High Power Electron Accelerator
paper.abstract: In this study, the idea 99Mo production using hybrid method based on electron accelerator has been pre-sented. Two different main production channels of 100Mo(γ,n)99Mo and 98Mo(n,γ)99Mo can be used for 99Mo production in this system. By considering high power Linac (30 MeV, 1 mA in average beam current) and one-stage approach, the calculation of 100Mo(γ,n)99Mo reactions in the optimized 100Mo target in two different designs (strip and disc) has been simu-lated. It is predicted that about 61 and 53 Ci of 99Mo activity per 24-hour irradiation on the strip target and the disc plates can be achieved, respectively. The threshold energy of photoneutron at 100Mo is about 9 MeV, so a large part of bremsstrahlung photons cannot participate in photoneutron reaction. For feasibility study, new hybrid approach has been tested by 10 MeV Rhodotron. Due to the low threshold of photo-neutron in deuteron (about 2.2 MeV) and significant low energy photons in 100Mo, photoneutron flux is available. So, Molybdenum target in heavy water Tank increases the production yield of 99Mo using neutron absorption reaction in 98Mo. The total activity of 99Mo has been predicted about 0.23 Ci per 24 hours e-beam irradiation.

paper.main_class: MC5: Beam Dynamics and EM Fields
paper.sub_class: D03 Calculations of EM Fields - Theory and Code Developments
paper.title: New Analytical Derivation of Group Velocity in TW Accelerating Structures
paper.abstract: Ultra high-gradient accelerating structures are needed for the next generation of compact light sources. In the framework of the Compact Light XLS project, we are studying a high harmonic traveling-wave accelerating structure operating at a frequency of 35.982 GHz, in order to linearize the longitudinal space phase. In this paper, we propose a new analytical approach for the estimation of the group velocity in the structure and we compare it with numerical electromagnetic simulations that are carried out by using the code HFSS in the frequency domain.

abstract_log.comments:
The contribution MOPGW030 reports on an analytic equation for the group velocity of a travelling wave structure. The motivation is to have a simple method to estimate the group velocity, without having to run complicated simulations. Overall, the paper is clearly presented and suitable for presentation at IPAC¿19.
- Comments:
- I agree with the numeric values of Eq.3, but not in Eq 4: For alpha=2.405/a, h = 0.08 lambda = 0.08 x 2.61 b = 0.2088 b, I obtain alpha h = 0.502164 b/a. Expanding, I obtain the coefficients 1, -0.502, +0.126, -0.0211, +0.0026 for (a/b)^3, (a/b)^2, (a/b), const, (b/a). I.e. the quadratic and constant term are slightly off. I suggest to double check. - One sentence on the duration of the HFSS simulations (seconds, minutes, days, weeks (?) on a normal CPU, cluster(?)), would be helpful to better appreciate the analytic equation. - Caption of Fig 4: With h=0.08 lambda and lambda=c/F I obtain h = 1mm for F=23.988 GHz and h = 0.667 mm for F=35.982 GHz. With the labels of Fig 4, F=23.988 GHz would correspond to the h=1mm blue-dashed line and F=35.982 GHz to the h=0.667mm black-solid line, but the caption says the opposite.
Minor comments:
- The references need to agree with style guide: title in italics, page numbers, include doi, etc¿ - \sin instead of `sin¿ in equations - last sentence of `Group Velocity Derivation¿: we observe that¿ -> We observe that (capital `W¿) - p2: it¿s -> it is - p2: Magnetic -> magnetic - captions Figures 6,7: Don¿t start sentence with a symbol. Suggestion: The ratio a/\lambda¿ The iris radius and RF wavelength are $a$ and $\lambda$, respectively. p3, last sentence left column: and 1.333 UNIT? p3, first sentence right column: ¿the cavity radius would be 3.434 UNITS? ¿ p3, right column: ¿ rather than ka -> rather than $k a$ (equation mode) - last sentence before the Conclusion: -> In this case, the energy change causes a SMALLER perturbation, (comma!) which leads to less frequency SHIFT and consequently gives a smallER group velocity variation. - Second to last sentence in the conclusion would be more readable, if split into two.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: Simulation of the Transition Radiation Transport Through an Optic System
paper.abstract: Optical Transition Radiation (OTR) screens are widely used for beam profile measurements. The radiation is emitted when a charged particle beam crosses the boundary between two media with different optical properties. The main advantages of OTR are the instantaneous emission process allowing fast single shot measurements (i.e. bunch by bunch measurements in a multi bunch machine), and the good linearity with the beam charge (if coherent effects can be neglected). Furthermore, OTR angular distribution strongly depends on beam energy. Since OTR screens are typically placed in several positions along the Linac to monitor beam envelope, one may perform a distributed energy measurement along the machine: this will be useful, for instance, during the commissioning phase of a machine. This paper deals with the studies of an algorithm to optimize the generation and the transport of the transition radiation through an optic system using the simulation tool Zemax. The algorithm, in combination with a particle tracking code (i.e. Elegant), will allow to simulate the radiation generated by a beam and, so, to take into account beam divergence and energy spread or chromatic effects in the optic system.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: High Level Software for Beam 6D Phase Space Characterization
paper.abstract: Operation of modern particle accelerators require high qualitity beams and conseguently sensitive diagnostic system in order to monitories and characterize the beam during the acceleration and transport. A turn-key high level software BOLINA (Beam Orbit for Linear Accelerators) has been developed to fully characterise the 6D beam phase space in order to help operator during commissioning with an easily scalable suite for any high brightness LINAC. In this work will be presented the diagnostic toolkit is presented as designed for the ELI-NP Gamma Beam System (GBS) a radiation source based on the Compton back scattering effect able to provide tunable gamma rays in the 0.2-20 MeV range with narrow bandwidth (0.3% and a high spectral density (10^4 photons/sec/eV) by the Compton backscattering effect. BOLINA suite is design to be machine independent, thanks to the file exchanges with the EPICS based control system. Simulation of raw data of the ELI-NP-GBS accelerator has been used to test the capabilities of the diagnostic toolkit.

paper.main_class: MC1: Circular and Linear Colliders
paper.title: Design of a Compact Power Distribution System for the ILC
paper.abstract: The Local power distribution system (LPDS) of the In-ternational Linear Collider (ILC) is constructed to transmit RF power from the 10 MW klystron to 39 cavi-ties. Each eight or nine 9-cell cavities is assembled in one cryomodule. The variable hybrid is used to adjust the power dividing ratio due to the different required power of each cavity and the variable phase shifter is used to compensate the phase drift caused by the variable hybrid. More compact LPDS is expected to be integrated on the cryomodule decreasing financial cost. We re-design the shorter variable hybrid with a margin of power ratio of ±25% and phase shifter of total phase range being 35° for compensating hybrid and on-crest searching. Fixed phase shifters are designed to adjust the phase difference between adjacent cavities for beam acceleration. Simu-lated results of total compact LPDS can meet the re-quirements of ILC.

paper.main_class: MC5: Beam Dynamics and EM Fields
paper.title: Analysis and Correction for the Effect of Multipoles with Skewed Errors on IP Beam Dynamics in SuperKEKB
paper.abstract: The beam dynamics at the interaction point (IP) in the accelerators which has the nano-beam scheme like as SuperKEKB is extremely sensitive for skewed error of final focusing magnets (QCS). As proceeding the beta squeezing in the interaction region (IR), the effect of optics aberrations at IP is enhanced. In the SuperKEKB Phase-2 commissioning, there was the problem come from skewed quadrupole fields in IR. The dominant skew parameters ``R" for this problem is very hard to see directly by using beam position monitors, thus it was corrected by scanning R parameters. In the next commissioning Phase-3 which is just before the operation with the Belle II experiment, it is planned that the IP beta squeezing is going forward to design parameters which is smaller than it achieved in Phase-2 by the factor of 4 (for horizontal beta) and 10 (for vertical beta). Hence the effect of skew error will be considerable larger and it is estimated that skew sextupoles will emerge as a serious cause for the aberration from the orbit. This report is the study of analysis and correction results for the effect of QCS skewed errors in the SuperKEKB commissioning.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Longitudinal-Phase-Space Manipulation for Efficient Beam-Driven Structure Wakefield Acceleration
paper.abstract: Collinear beam-driven structure wakefield acceleration (SWFA) is an advanced acceleration technique that could support the compact generation of high-energy beams for future multi-user x-ray free-electron-laser facilities*. Producing an ideal shaped drive beam through phase space manipulation is crucial for an efficient SWFA. Controlling the final longitudinal-phase space of the drive beam necessitate staged beam manipulations during acceleration. This paper describes the preliminary design of an accelerator beamline capable of producing drive beam with tailored current distribution and longitudinal-phase-space correlation. The proposed design is based on simple analytical models combined in a 1-D longitudinal beam-dynamics simulation tracking program supporting forward and backward (time reversal) tracking.
paper.agency: This work is funded by the United States Department of Energy awards DE-SC0018656 with Northern Illinois University and DE-AC02-06CH11357 with Argonne National Laboratory.
paper.footnote: * A. Zholents, et al., Dielectric wakefield accelerator to drive the future FEL light source

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.sub_class: A09 Muon Accelerators and Neutrino Factories
paper.title: Development of Inter-Digital H-Mode Drift-Tube Linac Prototype with Alternative Phase Focusing for a Muon Linac in the J-PARC Muon G-2/EDM Experiment
paper.abstract: An inter-digital H-mode drift-tube linac (IH-DTL) is developed in a muon linac at the J-PARC E34 experiment. IH-DTL will accelerate muons from 0.34 MeV to 4.5 MeV at a drive frequency of 324 MHz. Since IH-DTL adopts an APF method, with which the beam is focused in the transverse direction using the RF field only, the proper beam matching of the phase-space distribution is required before the injection into the IH-DTL. Thus, an IH-DTL prototype was fabricated to evaluate the performance of the cavity and beam transmission. As a preparation of the high-power test, a test coupler is designed and fabricated. In this paper, the development of the coupler and the result of the low-power measurement will be presented.
paper.agency: This work is supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Numbers JP15H03666, JP18H03707, JP16H03987, and JP16J07784.
